unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about using LaTeX for their class 10 Maths project. Honestly, it's a bit overkill for a basic project, but hey, if you're up for the challenge, go for it! It'll definitely make your work look super polished. Imagine, all those equations perfectly typeset! For example, the quadratic formula will look like this: `x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}`. It's much clearer than trying to write it by hand.
normalised: Okay, so someone asked about using L-A-T-E-X for their class ten Maths project. Honestly, it is a bit overkill for a basic project, but hey, if you are up for the challenge, go for it! It will definitely make your work look super polished. Imagine, all those equations perfectly typeset! For example, the quadratic formula will look like this: x equals negative b plus or minus the square root of b squared minus four a c, all divided by two a. It is much clearer than trying to write it by hand.

But seriously, consider the time investment. If your project is due on twentieth July two thousand and twenty four and you have five other subjects to worry about, maybe stick to what you know unless you really are super keen to spend hours mastering a new skill. I remember spending almost three days trying to get my equations perfectly aligned for a presentation in college, and I nearly missed my project deadline.

normalised: Ultimately, it depends on how much time and effort you are willing to put in. If you are just aiming for a good grade and not planning on using L-A-T-E-X again anytime soon, maybe it is not worth it. But if you see it as a long-term skill that could be useful for future projects or research, then definitely give it a shot! You can even try including some complex expressions and equations, like integral from zero to infinity of e to the power of negative x squared d x equals the square root of pi divided by two. Just make sure you can actually explain the Maths behind it!
